title: R43398
content: The federal government has been involved in collecting educational statistics for over 150 years. The National Institute of Education (NIE) and the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) were established in the 1970s to centralize research efforts. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) replaced the NIE in 2002, becoming an independent research institute within the Department of Education. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) as an independent research institute within the Department of Education. ESRA also created the National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) to advise the Director of IES and established three National Education Centers: the National Center for Education Research (NCER), the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), and the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance (NCEE). Additionally, P.L. 108-446 added a fourth center to operate within IES. P.L. 108-446 amended ESRA by adding the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) to the Institute of Education Sciences (IES). Along with ESRA, P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ETAA provides grants for technical assistance activities, while NAEPAA authorizes national and state assessments in reading and mathematics for grades 4, 8, and 12. These changes have impacted federal educational research and statistics activities. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) led to the creation of an independent research institute, the Institute of Education Sciences (IES), with more freedom from the Department of Education (ED). ESRA also established scientifically-based standards for educational research, providing greater oversight through a technical panel (NBES) compared to previous legislation. ESRA established scientifically-based standards for educational research, requiring methodological rigor for IES-supported research. Funding for ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA has continued through annual appropriations legislation. In the 113th and 114th Congress, bills were passed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA with amendments related to IES. The House of Representatives passed H.R. 4366, and the Senate adopted S. 227, both bills aimed at reauthorizing ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA with amendments related to IES. The report provides a concise description of programs and authorities established by these acts, organized in alignment with P.L. 107-279. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) under P.L. 107-279 establishes IES as a research institute within the Department of Education. IES aims to provide information on education progress, practices for academic improvement, and program effectiveness through research, statistics, and evaluations. The IES Director is appointed by the President and carries out specific duties such as proposing research priorities. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) establishes IES as a research institute within the Department of Education. The IES Director is appointed by the President and has specific duties such as proposing research priorities and ensuring activities are objective and free of bias. ESRA also authorizes the NBES to advise and consult with the Director on policies and funding decisions. The Board advises on research priorities, procedures for review, funding decisions, and Commissioner appointments for IES research centers. ESRA specifies Board requirements and IES composition with four research centers. Commissioners are appointed for a term not exceeding six years. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) is one of four research centers under the Institute of Education Sciences (IES), each with specific duties outlined in the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA). NCER's mission is to sponsor research that ensures all children have access to quality education, improves academic achievement, closes achievement gaps, and promotes postsecondary education opportunities. Its duties include sponsoring sustained research, supporting synthesis of research, promoting quality scientific inquiry, and validating research findings. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) supports research to improve academic achievement, close achievement gaps, and promote postsecondary education opportunities. Its duties include maintaining peer-review processes, proposing research plans, and supporting national research centers on various education topics. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) supports research on various education topics through research and development centers. These centers focus on areas such as adult literacy, teacher quality, and reading. Grants are awarded for up to five years, with a maximum of 10 years of support without a competitive process. The Commissioner of NCER oversees a research plan that includes basic and applied research, field-initiated research efforts, and ongoing initiatives. The Director of IES must contract with 10 Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) to provide technical assistance for education research and evaluation. RELs support applied research, dissemination, and training for SEAs, LEAs, and school boards on ESEA implementation, teaching methods, and educational practices. NCSER sponsors research to enhance services for infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities and supports the implementation of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) sponsors research to improve services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), evaluate its implementation, and identify scientifically based practices and interventions to support learning and academic achievement for children with disabilities. NCSER also focuses on improving personnel preparation, addressing overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, and examining the special needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) focuses on assessments for students with significant cognitive disabilities, overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, improving personnel preparation, excess cost of educating students with disabilities, and special needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities. NCSER conducts research activities, awards grants, and disseminates findings. The National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) established the National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) and mandated the Commissioner of Education Statistics to conduct the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP). NAEP includes national and state assessment programs, a long-term trend study, and a trial urban district assessment program. The national assessment program evaluates student achievement in reading and mathematics every two years for grades 4 and 8, with assessments in other subjects for grade 12. Funding for these activities continued through annual appropriations legislation after the authorities expired in FY2008. The National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) includes national and state assessment programs in reading and mathematics for grades 4 and 8, with assessments in other subjects for grade 12. Participation in the NAEP assessment is voluntary for students, schools, and local educational agencies. The Assessment Board, consisting of various stakeholders, formulates policy guidelines for NAEP and selects the subject areas to be assessed. The Assessment Board for the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) includes state legislators, school officers, educators, and experts. Their duties include selecting subjects to assess, setting achievement levels, developing test specifications, involving stakeholders in the assessment process, and ensuring validity and reliability of assessments for grades 4, 8, and 12. The National Assessment Governing Board designs assessment methodology, measures student academic achievement in grades 4, 8, and 12, develops guidelines for reporting results, and plans the release of NAEP reports. Funding for these activities has been ongoing through annual appropriations legislation. The National Assessment Governing Board receives funding through annual appropriations legislation for activities related to the NAEP. Legislation in the 113th and 114th Congress aimed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, proposing changes to IES independence, research standards, and accountability. Both bills would have given the Director of IES more authority and the ability to appoint the Commissioner of NCES. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 proposed giving the Director of IES more authority, including the ability to appoint the Commissioner of NCES and establish the NBES as independent. They also aimed to ensure practitioner representation on the NBES board and allow for the Director of IES to serve for up to two six-year terms.
